weeks.label: Week 1: How web works?
weeks.summary: Understand HTTP, the browser, the Client-Server model, create your first HTML, The head & body HTML, tables.

days.label: Day 1
days.description: Start Coding right away! Explan the internet architecture in 5 minutes, then explain how the browser works and how HTTP works with one example. Then start coding right away, do the postcard and explain the tags as you use then in the project. Students should code the project with your lead.
days.homework: The students must finish the Postcard on their own (there is a video-tutorial)

days.label: Day 2
days.description: Conecting CSS & HTML: Finish the postcard and start the Instagram Feed. Review all the key concepts with your students.
days.homework: Students must finish the Instagram & the Postcard.
key-concepts: Do not use ID as CSS selectors (use specificity)

days.label: Day 3
days.description: Explain bootstrap and how it solves 99% of the pain. Everything is a component from now own.
key-concepts: Workflow: Identify the components, Copy&Paste them and finally customize them

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Students must finish all pending proyects!

weeks.label: Week 2: Wireframes, CMD & GIT
weeks.summary: Time to start having a professional workflow

days.label: Day 4
days.description: Teach the command line to your students, use the CMD challenge to make it very fun! Start with a small explanation about the importance of the CMD and then explain each command after its respective challenge is completed.
days.homework: At the end of the class, present the students with the GIT project & please ask each student to start coding its corresponding part of the website.

days.label: Day 5
days.description: Time to explain and practice with GIT in detail, create a repository for your Landing Page GIT proyect and make them clone it and upload their piece of the proyect. Review the key concepts.
days.homework: At the end of the class, present the students with the GIT project & please ask each student to start coding its corresponding part of the Landing Page. Suggested parts: navbar, jumbotron, 2 parts description, product showcase, marketing banner, contact us, footer

days.label: Day 6
days.description: Make the students design a wireframe starting from the typical client requierment specs, teach them the importance of using components and how to pick them and draw a wireframe before jumping into coding.
days.homework: Finished Replits and Projects

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Students must finish HTML, CSS3, Layout, Bootstrap, GIT and deliver all the projects througouht the online platform

weeks.label: Week 3: First coding skills
weeks.summary: Learn to loop, work with arrays, if..else and functions. Create algorithms.

days.label: Day 7
days.description: The excuse generator is a great way to explain how Javascript and HTML/CSS can play together. Do it with the students as you explain all the programing Key Concepts
days.homework: Students need to make the replits about javascript and the layout for the Random Card Generator

days.label: Day 8
days.description: Finish the excuse generator and help the students do as many replits as they can during class, make sure to help them progress as much as you want in the arrays, loops, conditionals, functions, etc.

project.title: Replit session: Do the replits with the students

days.label: Day 9
days.description: Let's do the Random Card but focusing a lot on the workflow (how to plan and begin coding), re-inforce the ONLOAD and PRE-LOAD main events and how to change CSS with JS
days.homework: Finish the Random Card and pending replits, start DOM & EVENTS replits
key-concepts: Using Math.random() GLOBAL Function to pick the cards and suites
Use querySelector() to select DOM Elements just like you do with CSS
Add/Remove CSS Classes to DOM elements

days.label: Weekend
days.description: During the weekend, students must finish all the replits

weeks.label: Week 4: React.js introduction
weeks.warning: You need to be confortable looping already

days.label: Day 10
days.description: Explain the professional workflow in JS: Why Webpack created bundles? Whay use JS Modules? How organize your code, transpile with babel for cros-browser support, Javascript Emac2018. Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.
days.homework: Students must have the CSS and HTML for the TodoList already finished and separated in two components: The whole list and each task on the list.
key-concepts: Please do not attempt to explain the Webpack Config.

days.label: Day 11
days.description: React as rendering engine: Students need to understand that now they can finally create their own HTML tags (React Components) and how to use the State and the Props

project.title: Continue with: Todo list with React

key-concepts: Using props to pass information to the parent component
days.homework: Students must finish the TodoList being able to add & delete tasks.

days.label: Day 12
days.description: React Router + Flux: How to create components that behave like Flux.Views (layouts) and math them with URL Routers. Demonstrate component lifecycle methods: WillMount, DidMount and willUnmount. Finally demonstrate the flux Action-Model-View workflow
days.homework: Students must create a contact managment app using React Router, Flux & Component lifecycle methods

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Finish the TodoList with React Router + Flux
days.homework: Finish the TodoList with React Router + Flux

weeks.label: Week 5: The Project!
weeks.summary: Time to start working on the project

days.label: Day 13
days.description: Explain User Stories and the SCRUM methodology. Students must pick their projects & partner, and start building the user stories on Trello.com, create the board with them.
days.homework: Students must finish the user stories by next class, remember that the student projects must meet certain conditions to be accepted.

days.label: Day 14
days.description: Review student project Boards and User Stories, fix their errors and make them wireframe their entire project
key-concepts: Students will deliver bad written stories, sit with them and re-explain the best practices
days.homework: Finish Wireframes and code the HTML/CSS for your first home Flux.View

days.label: Day 15
days.description: Students must have all the MVP stories and wireframes finished, now it's time to start coding them, thei should turn their HTML/CSS into a Flux.View and separate everything into components
key-concepts: Using the React Debugging Chrome Plugin
Debugging code with the Chrome Source Tab
days.homework: Sit with every project team and discuss how to split the code into Flux.Views and React.Components, students must finish the home layout by next class

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Student Projects Flux.Views must be finished by next class

weeks.label: Week 6: Flux.Model to Flux.View
weeks.summary: No more hard-coding, make your Flux.Views and Components render from the Flux.Model

days.label: Day 16
days.description: Now with map the Flux.Views user actions into Flux.Actions and greate the Flux.Model setters for them. The Flux.Views are able to get the Flux.Store data through the public getters.
days.homework: Students must add all the application actions into Flux.Actions and start linking them to the Flux.Views, also start dispatching the actions to the Stores if possible
key-concepts: How to map map user actions to Flux.Actions
What to save on the store and what to save locally on the Views/Comopnents States
Why are the model setters private?
How to listen to the emit?

days.label: Day 17
days.description: Finally students must use the Flux.Store getters to retreive the data into the views, they should understand the flow: store changes > views listen > views get the new info and set into the local state > views re-render
key-concepts: Create some sample data on your Flux.Model
Create the getters to get that data from the views
Create the listeners to handle store changes
Re-set the views model on store changes
Re-render and conditionally display whatever is needed
Create any actions to change the models
Create the setters and update the store state
days.homework: Students must work on all their Flux.Views to make them work with store data, students must also work on polishing the CSS/HTML based on that

days.label: Day 18
days.description: Last day to complete your Flux.Views, Flux.Actions and Flux.Model
days.homework: Finish the project Views/Actions/Models

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Students must finish the AJAX Replits

weeks.label: Week 7: Ajax(HTTP-JSON)
weeks.topic: Send and Receive Data with HTTP

days.label: Day 19
days.description: Intro to AJAX: Re-Explain HTTP Requests but now using GET, POST, PUT & DELETE. Introduce JSON instead of HTML as the main communication format. Serialize and Unserialize.

project.title: Use the Contact Manage API to save, delete and update the contacts

key-concepts: How to use POSTMan, set environment variables and use collections
JSON is a Javascript object but as TEXT
The goal is to send/receive everything as JSON Serialize>Send>Unserialize
What is serialization and how to do it (Parsing)
Why using several request types (GET, POST, PUT, DELETE)?
Explan the 3 mains types content-types: Form, URL-Encoded, Raw (With JSON)
days.homework: Using postman, and then using Flux/React, students must consume the API to Save, Delete and Update Contacts.

days.label: Day 20
days.description: Finish the Contact Managment API integration, focus on Debugging procedures and start the introduction to Python
days.homework: Students must finish the Contact Managment API integration and advance a lot on the Python replits

days.label: Day 21
days.description: Install Django-Rest With your students using the Django Hello Boilerplate and create your fist API Methods, demonstrate how the urls.py, views.py, serializable.py and model.py work
days.homework: Build your own Contact Managment API

days.label: Weekend
days.description: Students must finish all the requests for the Django Contact Managment API
